logTitle: IELTS Reading Log: Attitudes towards Artificial Intelligence

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Artificial intelligence (AI) can already predict the future.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To say that an event or action will happen in the future, as a result of knowledge or experience

phase3Production.content: No one can accurately predict the future, but we can prepare for it.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Researchers are even trying to give AI imagination so it can plan for unexpected consequences.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Outcomes or effects that were not anticipated or foreseen
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Những hậu quả không lường trước được

phase3Production.content: The new policy had several unexpected consequences for the local economy.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Yet for all these technological advances, we still seem to deeply lack confidence in AI predictions.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Developments or improvements in technology

phase3Production.content: Recent technological advances have changed the way we work and live.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...we still seem to deeply lack confidence in AI predictions.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To have a profound or strong absence of trust or belief in something
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Thiếu niềm tin sâu sắc vào

phase3Production.content: Many voters deeply lack confidence in the political system.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Recent cases show that people don’t like relying on AI and prefer to trust human experts, even if these experts are wrong.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To choose to believe in the judgement of people rather than machines
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Thích tin tưởng các chuyên gia con người hơn

phase3Production.content: When it comes to medical diagnoses, many patients still prefer to trust human experts.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: To do that, we need to understand why people are so reluctant to trust AI in the first place.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Unwilling and hesitant to believe in the reliability, truth, or ability of something

phase3Production.content: After being lied to, she was reluctant to trust him again.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Take the case of Watson for Oncology, one of technology giant IBM’s supercomputer programs.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A very large and powerful technology company

phase3Production.content: The small startup was eventually acquired by a technology giant.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Their attempt to promote this program to cancer doctors was a PR disaster.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Một 'thảm họa' (disaster) 'về quan hệ công chúng' (PR)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: An event that receives very bad publicity and damages a company's or organization's public image

phase3Production.content: The product recall turned into a PR disaster for the company.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The AI promised to deliver top-quality recommendations on the treatment of 12 cancers...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Suggestions or advice of the highest standard
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Những khuyến nghị chất lượng hàng đầu

phase3Production.content: The consultant provided top-quality recommendations that greatly improved our business.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...12 cancers that accounted for 80% of the world’s cases.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To form a particular amount or part of something

phase3Production.content: Students from this city accounted for 30% of the university's total enrollment.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: On the one hand, if Watson provided guidance about a treatment that coincided with their own opinions, physicians did not see much point in Watson’s recommendations.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Trùng với' (coincided with) 'ý kiến' (opinions) 'của chính họ' (their own)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To happen at the same time or agree with their own views
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Trùng với ý kiến của chính họ

phase3Production.content: His findings coincided with the results of previous studies.

lexicalItems.targetLexeme: did not see much point in
lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...physicians did not see much point in Watson’s recommendations.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Không thấy có nhiều ý nghĩa' (did not see much point in)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To not understand the purpose or value of something
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Không thấy có nhiều ý nghĩa/giá trị
relatedCollocates: fail to see the value in

phase3Production.content: I did not see much point in arguing with him any further.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: On the other hand, if Watson generated a recommendation that contradicted the experts’ opinion, doctors would typically conclude that Watson wasn’t competent.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Mâu thuẫn với' (contradicted) 'ý kiến' (opinion) 'của chuyên gia' (the experts')

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To be in conflict with the view of the specialists
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Mâu thuẫn với ý kiến của chuyên gia

phase3Production.content: The new evidence contradicted the expert's opinion given in court.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...doctors would typically conclude that Watson wasn’t competent.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Not having the necessary ability, knowledge, or skill to do something successfully

phase3Production.content: He was fired because he wasn't competent to do the job.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: And the machine wouldn’t be able to explain why its treatment was plausible because its machine-learning algorithms were simply too complex to be fully understood by humans.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Phương pháp 'điều trị' (treatment) 'hợp lý/đáng tin cậy' (was plausible)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The medical care given was reasonable and likely to be effective
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Phương pháp điều trị là hợp lý

phase3Production.content: The doctor's explanation for his symptoms seemed plausible.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Consequently, this has caused even more suspicion and disbelief, leading many doctors to ignore the seemingly outlandish AI recommendations...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A feeling of doubt or mistrust combined with an inability to believe something
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Sự nghi ngờ và không tin tưởng

phase3Production.content: He looked at the impossible magic trick with a mixture of suspicion and disbelief.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...to ignore the seemingly outlandish AI recommendations and stick to their own expertise.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Appearing very strange or bizarre

phase3Production.content: She wore a seemingly outlandish hat to the party.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and stick to their own expertise.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Bám lấy/trung thành với' (stick to) 'chuyên môn' (expertise) 'của chính họ' (their own)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To continue to follow one's own specialized knowledge and skills
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Bám sát chuyên môn của chính họ

phase3Production.content: Despite the new trends, the chef decided to stick to his own expertise in classic French cuisine.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: This is just one example of people’s lack of confidence in AI and their reluctance to accept what AI has to offer.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: An unwillingness to agree to or receive something

phase3Production.content: There was a general reluctance to accept the new manager's proposals.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: This helps create a psychological feeling of safety.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Một 'cảm giác' (feeling) 'an toàn' (of safety) 'về mặt tâm lý' (psychological)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A mental or emotional state of being protected from harm or danger
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Cảm giác an toàn về mặt tâm lý

phase3Production.content: A stable home environment provides a child with a psychological feeling of safety.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: AI, on the other hand, is still fairly new and unfamiliar to most people.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Quite recent and not well known

phase3Production.content: The software was fairly new and unfamiliar, so it took some time to learn.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Even if it can be technically explained (and that’s not always the case), AI’s decision-making process is usually too difficult for most people to comprehend.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The cognitive process of reaching a decision

phase3Production.content: Understanding the customer's needs is a key part of the decision-making process.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...is usually too difficult for most people to comprehend.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To grasp mentally; to understand fully

phase3Production.content: The scale of the universe is something that is difficult for the human mind to comprehend.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: And interacting with something we don’t understand can cause anxiety and give us a sense that we’re losing control.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To make someone feel worried, nervous, or uneasy

phase3Production.content: Waiting for exam results can cause a lot of anxiety for students.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and give us a sense that we’re losing control.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Cảm giác rằng chúng ta đang 'mất kiểm soát' (losing control)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To no longer have the power to direct or influence events

phase3Production.content: The car skidded on the ice and he felt himself losing control.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Many people are also often not familiar with many instances of AI actually working...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Not having a good knowledge or understanding of something

phase3Production.content: I am not familiar with that particular theory.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...because it often happens in the background.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Thường 'xảy ra ở chế độ nền/một cách thầm lặng' (happens in the background)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To take place without being the main focus of attention; unobtrusively
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Xảy ra ở chế độ nền

phase3Production.content: A lot of the important data processing happens in the background, without the user seeing it.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Instead, they are acutely aware of instances where AI goes wrong.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Nhận thức sâu sắc/rõ rệt' (acutely aware of)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To be very conscious or have a strong realization of something

phase3Production.content: She was acutely aware of the tension in the room.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...instances where AI goes wrong.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Những trường hợp AI 'mắc lỗi/hoạt động sai' (goes wrong)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Situations where artificial intelligence fails, makes a mistake, or produces an undesirable outcome

phase3Production.content: We need to have contingency plans for situations where the AI goes wrong.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Embarrassing AI failures receive a disproportionate amount of media attention...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Một 'lượng' (amount) 'sự chú ý' (attention) 'của truyền thông' (media) 'không tương xứng' (disproportionate)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: An amount of coverage by the media that is too large or too small in comparison with something else
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Lượng chú ý không tương xứng của truyền thông

phase3Production.content: Minor celebrity scandals often receive a disproportionate amount of media attention.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Machine learning is not foolproof, in part because the humans who design it aren’t.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Không hoàn toàn đáng tin cậy/không thể sai lầm' (not foolproof)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Not incapable of going wrong or being misused

phase3Production.content: Even the most secure system is not foolproof against a determined hacker.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Feelings about AI run deep.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: (Of feelings or beliefs) to be very strong and well established

phase3Production.content: The cultural traditions in this community run deep.

lexicalItems.targetLexeme: depicted AI in a positive or negative light
lexicalItems.sourceContext: It was found that, regardless of whether the film they watched depicted AI in a positive or negative light, simply watching a cinematic vision of our technological future polarised the participants’ attitudes.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Mô tả' (depicted) 'AI' (AI) 'theo một góc nhìn' (in a light) 'tích cực' (positive) 'hay' (or) 'tiêu cực' (negative)

phase2Annotation.phonetic: /dɪˈpɪktɪd eɪ aɪ ɪn ə ˈpɒzətɪv ɔː ˈneɡətɪv laɪt/
phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To represent or show AI in either a favorable or unfavorable way
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Mô tả AI theo hướng tích cực hoặc tiêu cực

phase3Production.content: The documentary depicted the politician in a very negative light.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...simply watching a cinematic vision of our technological future polarised the participants’ attitudes.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Đã 'phân cực' (polarised) 'thái độ' (attitudes) 'của người tham gia' (the participants')

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To cause a group to divide into two opposing sides with very different opinions
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Phân cực thái độ của người tham gia

phase3Production.content: The controversial new law polarised public opinion.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Optimists became more extreme in their enthusiasm for AI and sceptics became even more guarded.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Những 'người hoài nghi' (sceptics) 'trở nên' (became) 'thận trọng/dè dặt' (guarded) 'hơn nữa' (even more)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: People inclined to question or doubt became even more cautious and reserved
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Những người hoài nghi càng trở nên dè dặt hơn

phase3Production.content: After the initial promises were not met, investors became more guarded.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: This suggests people use relevant evidence about AI in a biased manner to support their existing attitudes...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: In a way that shows unfair prejudice for or against someone or something

phase3Production.content: The news report presented the information in a biased manner.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...a deep-rooted human tendency known as “confirmation bias”.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Một 'khuynh hướng' (tendency) 'của con người' (human) 'đã ăn sâu' (deep-rooted)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A strong and long-standing inclination to behave in a certain way
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Khuynh hướng đã ăn sâu của con người

phase3Production.content: Procrastination is a deep-rooted human tendency that is difficult to overcome.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...a deep-rooted human tendency known as “confirmation bias”.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The tendency to search for, interpret, favor, and recall information in a way that confirms or supports one's preexisting beliefs

phase3Production.content: Confirmation bias leads people to ignore evidence that contradicts their views.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...it could lead to a society split between those who benefit from AI and those who reject it.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A community that is divided into two opposing groups
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Một xã hội bị chia rẽ giữa

phase3Production.content: The political issue created a society split between the young and the old.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: More pertinently, refusing to accept the advantages offered by AI could place a large group of people at a serious disadvantage.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: In a situation that makes it much harder for one to succeed or have an equal opportunity
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Ở thế bất lợi nghiêm trọng

phase3Production.content: Students without access to a computer are at a serious disadvantage.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Simply having previous experience with AI can significantly improve people’s opinions about the technology...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Past encounters or familiarity with something

phase3Production.content: Having previous experience with this software is a requirement for the job.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Another solution may be to reveal more about the algorithms which AI uses and the purposes they serve.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To make more known about something that was secret or previously unknown

phase3Production.content: The investigation is expected to reveal more about the company's financial dealings.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...the algorithms which AI uses and the purposes they serve.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The functions they perform or the goals they are intended to achieve
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Mục đích mà chúng phục vụ

phase3Production.content: It's important to understand the tools we use and the purposes they serve.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Several high-profile social media companies and online marketplaces already release transparency reports...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Các 'công ty' (companies) 'truyền thông xã hội' (social media) 'nổi tiếng' (high-profile)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Very famous and well-known companies in the social media sector
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các công ty truyền thông xã hội nổi tiếng

phase3Production.content: High-profile social media companies are facing increased scrutiny over data privacy.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...already release transparency reports about government requests and surveillance disclosures.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Public reports issued by companies detailing requests they have received from governments for user data

phase3Production.content: The company publishes annual transparency reports to build trust with its users.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...about government requests and surveillance disclosures.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The act of making information about monitoring and observation public
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Việc tiết lộ thông tin giám sát

phase3Production.content: Activists are calling for greater surveillance disclosures from intelligence agencies.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: A similar practice for AI could help people have a better understanding of the way algorithmic decisions are made.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Choices or judgments made by an algorithm
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các quyết định theo thuật toán

phase3Production.content: We need to ensure that algorithmic decisions are fair and unbiased.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Research suggests that allowing people some control over AI decision-making could also improve trust and enable AI to learn from human experience.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To make it possible for artificial intelligence to acquire knowledge or skills

phase3Production.content: The vast amount of data will enable the AI to learn and improve its predictions.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...when people were allowed the freedom to slightly modify an algorithm, they felt more satisfied with its decisions...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To make small changes to a set of rules used in calculations
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Sửa đổi một chút thuật toán

phase3Production.content: The programmer had to slightly modify the algorithm to improve its accuracy.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...they felt more satisfied with its decisions...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To feel a greater sense of pleasure or contentment with something
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Cảm thấy hài lòng hơn với

phase3Production.content: After the changes were made, customers felt more satisfied with the service.

lexicalItems.targetLexeme: more likely to believe it was superior
lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...more likely to believe it was superior and more likely to use it in the future.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Có nhiều khả năng' (more likely) 'tin rằng' (to believe) 'nó' (it) 'vượt trội hơn' (was superior)

phase2Annotation.phonetic: /mɔː ˈlaɪkli tə bɪˈliːv ɪt wəz suːˈpɪəriə/
phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To have a greater probability of thinking that it was better than others
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Có nhiều khả năng tin rằng nó vượt trội hơn

phase3Production.content: After seeing the demonstration, they were more likely to believe the new product was superior.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: We don’t need to understand the intricate inner workings of AI systems...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The very complicated internal mechanisms or processes of how something operates
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Cách hoạt động bên trong phức tạp

phase3Production.content: Few people understand the intricate inner workings of a computer's processor.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...but if people are given a degree of responsibility for how they are implemented, they will be more willing to accept AI into their lives.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A certain level of duty or control over something

phase3Production.content: Giving employees a degree of responsibility can increase their job satisfaction.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...they will be more willing to accept AI into their lives.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To be more ready or prepared to agree to or receive something

phase3Production.content: After seeing the benefits, she was more willing to accept the new technology.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Optimists became more extreme in their enthusiasm for AI and sceptics became even more guarded.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: People who tend to be hopeful and confident about the future or the success of something

phase3Production.content: Optimists believe that technology will solve many of the world's problems.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and sceptics became even more guarded.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: People inclined to question or doubt all accepted opinions

phase3Production.content: The sceptics in the audience were not convinced by his presentation.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: More pertinently, refusing to accept the advantages offered by AI could place a large group of people at a serious disadvantage.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: In a way that relates directly and significantly to the matter at hand

phase3Production.content: The report was well-researched and, more pertinently, it offered practical solutions.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: More pertinently, refusing to accept the advantages offered by AI could place a large group of people at a serious disadvantage.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Indicating or showing that one is not willing to agree to or receive something

phase3Production.content: Refusing to accept help can sometimes make a situation worse.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Several high-profile social media companies and online marketplaces already release transparency reports...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: E-commerce sites where products or services are provided by multiple third parties
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các sàn giao dịch trực tuyến

phase3Production.content: Many small businesses sell their products through large online marketplaces.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...release transparency reports about government requests and surveillance disclosures.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Official demands made by a government for information or action
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các yêu cầu của chính phủ

phase3Production.content: The company complied with the government requests for user data.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: A similar practice for AI could help people have a better understanding...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A comparable method or customary way of doing something

phase3Production.content: A similar practice is followed in many other countries.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...when people were allowed the freedom to slightly modify an algorithm...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Sự tự do' (the freedom) 'để sửa đổi một chút' (to slightly modify)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The power or right to make small changes to something
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Sự tự do sửa đổi một chút

phase3Production.content: The software gives users the freedom to slightly modify the interface.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...if people are given a degree of responsibility for how they are implemented, they will be more willing to accept AI...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To put a decision, plan, or agreement into effect

phase3Production.content: The new policies will be implemented starting next month.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...they will be more willing to accept AI into their lives.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To consent to receive or integrate AI as part of one's daily existence
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Chấp nhận AI vào cuộc sống

phase3Production.content: It may take time for the older generation to fully accept AI into their lives.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Police forces are using it to map when and where crime is likely to occur.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The body of police officers in a particular country or area

phase3Production.content: Police forces around the world are adopting new technologies to fight crime.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Many decisions in our lives require a good forecast, and AI is almost always better at forecasting than we are.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The act of predicting or estimating a future event or trend

phase3Production.content: Weather forecasting has become much more accurate with the help of supercomputers.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...reluctant to trust AI in the first place.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Used to introduce the first or most important in a list of reasons or points; from the beginning

phase3Production.content: I don't know why he went there in the first place.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: On the one hand, if Watson provided guidance about a treatment that coincided with their own opinions...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Used to present the first of two contrasting points, facts, or ways of looking at something

phase3Production.content: On the one hand, the new job offers a higher salary, but on the other hand, it requires longer hours.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: On the other hand, if Watson generated a recommendation that contradicted the experts’ opinion...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Used to present the second of two contrasting points, facts, or ways of looking at something

phase3Production.content: The city is vibrant and exciting. On the other hand, it can be very crowded and expensive.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Consequently, this has caused even more suspicion and disbelief...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: As a result; therefore

phase3Production.content: He missed his flight and, consequently, was late for the meeting.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Trust in other people is often based on our understanding of how others think and having experience of their reliability.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Dựa trên 'sự hiểu biết của chúng ta' (our understanding)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Founded on one's knowledge or interpretation of something
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Dựa trên sự hiểu biết của chúng ta

phase3Production.content: We made our decision based on our understanding of the current market trends.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and having experience of their reliability.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Có 'kinh nghiệm' (experience) 'về' (of) 'sự đáng tin cậy' (their reliability) 'của họ' (their)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Knowledge or skill gained through involvement in or exposure to how dependable someone is
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Kinh nghiệm về độ tin cậy của họ

phase3Production.content: We chose that car brand because we have years of experience of their reliability.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...simply watching a cinematic vision of our technological future polarised the participants’ attitudes.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A depiction or representation of something that is characteristic of films

phase3Production.content: The director is known for his unique cinematic vision.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Optimists became more extreme in their enthusiasm for AI...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Trở nên 'cực đoan hơn' (more extreme) 'trong' (in) 'sự nhiệt tình' (their enthusiasm) 'của họ' (their)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To become more intense or radical in one's eager interest
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Cực đoan hơn trong sự nhiệt tình

phase3Production.content: As the team kept winning, the fans became more extreme in their enthusiasm.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: This suggests people use relevant evidence about AI in a biased manner...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Information or facts that are closely connected or appropriate to what is being done or considered

phase3Production.content: The lawyer presented relevant evidence to support his client's case.
